questions.text: Which among the following indicates Severe COVID?

options.label: C
options.text: Lung In-filterate. More than 42% infiltrates on CT

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spo2< 85% on room air Spo2<90% on room air indicates severe covid

questions.text: High output cardiac failure seen in all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cor pulmonale High output cardiac failure is seen in all except cor pulmonale

Highyeild:

Patients with high output cardiac failure have normal cardiac function and decreased systemic vascular resistance, either secondary to diffuse arteriolar dilation or possible bypass of the arterioles and capillary beds, leading to activation of neurohormones Pathophysiology Increase in the body’s demand for blood from increased metabolism Bypass of the arteriolar and capillary bed causing an increased flow into venous circulation Causes Metabolic A. Hyperthyroidism B. Myeloproliferative disorders Myocardial A. Sepsis B. Wet Beriberi due to thiamine deficiency C. Chronic lung disease Peripheral Vascular Arteriovenous fistulas (AVF), congenital or acquired Liver cirrhosis is associated with arteriovenous shunts and decreased systemic vascular resistance Chronic severe anemia Morbid obesity

Extraedge:

NYHA Classification - The Stages of Heart Failure

questions.text: Identify the ana pattern given in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Centromeric The given picture shows discrete and large speckles in the resting cells and the alignment of the speckles in the chromosome region in the dividing cells. Anti centromere bodies are specific markers associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, also known as limited scleroderma (CREST Syndrome). These antibodies target the centromere proteins on the chromosomes.

Extraedge:

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA. Seen in systemic sclerosis Speckled pattern refers to hundreds of dots present throughout the nucleus. There is no chromosomal staining. Pattern shown by-anti-SS -A/Ro and anti-SS-B/La antibodies Homogenous pattern refers to diffuse staining of the chromosome region in the dividing cells. Seen in Juvenile idiopathic arthritis, Chronic autoimmune hepatitis

Solution:

Torsades de pointes The given ECG shows broad QRS tachycardia with changing QRS morphology with every beat. The most likely diagnosis in this case is polymorphic ventricular tachycardia or Torsades de pointes.

Highyeild:

Torsades de pointes (TdP) is a specific type of arrhythmia that can lead to ventricular tachycardia. It is characterized by a distinct pattern of the heart’s electrical activity on an electrocardiogram (ECG), where the QRS complexes appear to twist around the baseline. TdP is often associated with prolonged QT intervals on the ECG Causative factors Medications: Many drugs can cause QT interval prolongation and increase the risk of TdP. These include certain antibiotics, antiarrhythmic drugs, antipsychotics, and more Electrolyte Imbalances: Hypokalemia, Hypomagnesemia, Hypocalcemia Congenital Long QT Syndrome Myocardial infarction, Myocarditis Bradycardia Female Gender: TdP tends to occur more frequently in females Endocrine disorders : Hypothyroidism, Pheochromocytoma

:

Explanation for other options: - Option B. Ventricular fibrillation It shows a rhythm which is completely disorganized,there is no identifiable waves on ECG Option C. Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia shows wide QRS complex tachycardia and there is the same QRS morphology in each beat. Seen in cardiomyopathy, scarring after myocardial infarction. Option D. Atrial flutter It shows sawtooth appearance of the P waves It is due to rapid and successive atrial depolarization.

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is an AR murmur likely to be heard?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ventricular diastole Ventricular diastole is characterized by opening of Aorto Pulmonary valves. Aortic regurgitation is a ventricular diastolic murmur heard in the Left 3rd intercostal space

questions.text: Order in which the following heart sounds are heard from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall? Pulmonary Aortic Mitral Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a, b, c The correct order for auscultation of the heart sound from superior to inferior is pulmonary>aortic>mitral 1. Pulmonary : Second intercostal space 2. Aortic : Can be auscultated in the neoaortic area or th erb’s 3. Mitral : Fifth intercostal space

Highyeild:

Auscultation on the right side : The aortic valve can be heard in the 2nd intercostal space along the edge of the sternum The tricuspid can be heard a little lower in the 5th intercostal space Auscultation on the left side: The pulmonary valve can be heard opposite the aortic valve, in the 2nd intercostal space along the edge of the sternum The mitral valve can be heard in the 5th intercostal space a little more laterally, in the midclavicular line.

questions.text: Amyloid found in renal dialysis is :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A beta 2 microglobulin Dialysis related amyloidosis is a common complication encountered in patients receiving chronic hemodialysis. A Beta 2-microglobulin(beta 2-m) constitutes the causative protein of amyloidosis, and its deposition in tissues has been proven to be a primary cause of the onset.

Highyeild:

Beta-2 microglobulin (B2M) is a small protein that is a component of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules, which are found on the surface of most cells in the body. In healthy individuals, the kidneys filter out excess B2M, and it is excreted in the urine. Dialysis-related amyloidosis is a disabling disease characterized by accumulation and tissue deposition of amyloid fibrils consisting of beta2-microglobulin (beta2-m) in the bone, periarticular structures, and viscera of patients with chronic kidney disease. High levels of B2M in body fluids are often caused by blood and bone marrow cancers like Multiple myeloma, Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and certain types of lymphoma.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option B. ATTR amyloidosis is caused by a protein called transthyretin, or TTR, that changes its shape and forms into fibrous clumps. These clumps of misshapen protein are deposited into various organs and peripheral nerves. Option C. Primary or light chain (AL) amyloidosis is the most common type of systemic amyloidosis. It is a protein misfolding and metabolism disorder in which insoluble fibrils are deposited in various tissues, causing organ dysfunction and eventually death Option D. AA amyloidosis is a disorder characterized by the extracellular tissue deposition of fibrils that are composed of fragments of and/or intact serum amyloid A protein (SAA), a hepatic acute phase reactant

questions.text: A patient presented with dysuria and pain in the back. His lumbar spine X- ray shows the below finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperparathyroidism The given clinical scenario and X-ray showing diffuse calcification of both kidneys are suggestive of nephrocalcinosis which is seen in hyperparathyroidism

Highyeild:

Nephrocalcinosis refers to generalized calcium deposition in the kidney and does not include the focal calcium deposition associated with focal renal injury Presentation Most commonly presents as an asymptomatic , chronic disease incidentally discovered on radiographic imaging of the abdomen Renal colic. Polyuria and polydipsia can occur with chronic hypercalcemia, medullary nephrocalcinosis, and in Bartter syndrome. Acute renal failure in instances such as tumor lysis syndrome and acute phosphate nephropathy Treatment is directed to treat the underlying cause of nephrocalcinosis. Strategies to reduce the urinary concentration of calcium, phosphate, or oxalate Increased fluid intake Potassium citrate to treat hypocitraturia and pH less than 7 in Distal renal tubular acidosis

Extraedge:

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism The signs and symptoms of primary hyperparathyroidism are classically summarized by the mnemonic “stones, bones, abdominal groans and psychiatric moans” Stones refers to kidney stones, nephrocalcinosis and diabetes insipidus (polyuria and polydipsia). These can ultimately lead to renal failure. Bones refers to bone-related complications. The classic bone disease in hyperparathyroidism is osteitis fibrosa cystica, which results in pain and pathological fractures. Other bone diseases associated with hyperparathyroidism are osteoporosis, osteomalacia, and arthritis. Abdominal groans refers to gastrointestinal symptoms of indigestion, nausea, vomiting and constipation. Hypercalcaemia can lead to peptic ulcers and acute pancreatitis. Mental moans refers to effects on the central nervous system. Symptoms include psychosis, anxiety, lethargy, memory loss, depression and coma. Acronym for features of Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A patient with a cough and fever came to the emergency room. On gram staining and microscopy only rhinovirus was isolated. RFT findings are Creatinine 1.5 and BUN 45. Patient is shifted to ICU following an X ray. What is the treatment of choice in this patient ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin Chest X-ray is suggestive of pneumonia on the right side and the patient history is also pointing towards it. As the patient is shifted to ICU, due to deranged RFT, he needs to be started on iv Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin

Highyeild:

Note : Combination therapy with a macrolide and a β-lactam is associated with better outcomes in patients with pneumonia. Severe pneumococcal pneumonia should be treated with beta lactam plus macrolide antibiotic combination therapy to achieve a better prognosis than with beta lactam monotherapy

Extraedge:

CURB 65 score for pneumonia severity estimates mortality of community-acquired pneumonia to help determine inpatient vs. outpatient treatment Confusion (based upon a specific mental test or new disorientation to person, place, or time) Urea (blood urea nitrogen in the United States) >7 mmol/L (20 mg/dL) Respiratory rate ≥30 breaths/minute Blood pressure (systolic The CURB-65 scores range from 0 to 5. Clinical management decisions can be made based on the score, as follows

questions.text: A person comes to the OPD with symptoms of not using his left side and not washing the left side of his body while bathing. On examination, he wasn’t able to draw the left side of the images. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right posterior inferior cortex The given presentation and image suggest hemispatial on the left side. This is likely due to a contralateral (right) parietal lobe lesion.

Highyeild:

The right hemisphere of the brain directs attention within the entire extrapersonal space - both right and left side. If there is a lesion in the left hemisphere, there is not much contralesional neglect because the right hemisphere can compensate for both sides. The left hemisphere directs attention only in the contralateral right hemispace. If there is a lesion in the right hemisphere, it leads to severe contralesional hemineglect because the left hemisphere does not contain ipsilateral attention functions. Patients with neglect may not be able to dress or groom the left side of the body. They may fail to copy the details on the left side of a drawing. Two bedside tests can be used to evaluate neglect: In simultaneous bilateral stimulation, when the examiner provides unilateral or simultaneous bilateral stimulation in the visual, auditory, or tactile modalities, patients have no difficulty detecting unilateral stimuli on either side but perceive the bilaterally presented stimulus as coming only from one side. This phenomenon is known as extinction. In visual target cancellation, the patient fails to detect the targets on one half of the field in target detection tasks.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A. Left posterior inferior cortex : Location: Posterior Inferior Cortex (Cerebellum) Function: The cerebellum is responsible for coordinating voluntary movements, maintaining balance and posture, fine-tuning motor skills, and supporting some cognitive functions. Effects of Lesion: A lesion in the posterior inferior cortex (cerebellum) can lead to a range of motor-related and cognitive deficits, depending on the specific area affected. Possible Symptoms: Motor Coordination Issues: Difficulties in coordinating movements, resulting in unsteady gait, tremors, and jerky movements. Balance Problems: Impaired ability to maintain balance and posture, leading to falls or unsteady movements. Dysmetria: Overreaching or underreaching of movements due to disrupted coordination. Dysarthria: Speech difficulties characterized by slurred or unclear speech. Nystagmus: Involuntary eye movements, often causing visual disturbances. Cognitive Changes: Some cognitive functions such as executive functions (planning, decision-making) may be affected, but the cerebellum’s exact role in cognition is still being researched. Option B. Left motor cortex : Location: Left Motor Cortex Function: Controls voluntary movements on the right side of the body Effects of Lesion: A lesion in the left motor cortex can lead to various motor-related deficits primarily affecting the right side of the body. This is because the brain’s wiring causes the left motor cortex to control movements on the right side and vice versa. The primary motor cortex on the left side of the brain controls movement of the right side of the body, and vice-versa, the right motor cortex controls movement of the left side of the body. Option C. Right motor cortex : Location: Right Motor Cortex Function: Controls voluntary movements on the left side of the body. Effects of Lesion: A lesion in the right motor cortex can result in various motor-related deficits primarily affecting the left side of the body. This is because the brain’s organization causes the right motor cortex to control movements on the left side and vice versa.

questions.text: Most specific indicator of alcohol induced liver dysfuction is ___________
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GAMMA -GT The best marker for alcohol induced liver damage is GAMMA-GT

Highyeild:

GGT İs commonly used in patients with alcoholic liver disease as a marker of excessive alcohol intake. GGT İs present in many tissues, including the kidneys, pancreas, and liver. It is mainly derived from the liver and this is often used as a marker of hepatobiliary diseases. Chronic alcohol consumption leads to the induction of hepatic microsomal GGT which leads to a rise in GGT in alcoholics. Laboratory investigations in patients with alcohol-induced liver dysfunction: AST (SGOT) and ALT (SGPT) elevations that do not exceed 400 |U/L. AST/ALT ratio of >1.5. Serum bilirubin >3 mg/dL

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A. SGOT: Elevated SGOT/AST Levels: When the liver is damaged due to alcohol consumption, such as in conditions like alcoholic hepatitis or alcoholic liver disease, SGOT/AST levels can become elevated. However, elevated SGOT/AST levels are not solely specific to alcohol-induced liver damage and can also occur in other liver diseases, viral hepatitis, drug-induced liver injury, and other conditions. An SGOT/SGPT ratio greater than 2 is highly suggestive of alcoholic hepatitis and cirrhosis. Option B. SGPT: Elevated SGPT/ALT Levels: Excessive alcohol consumption can lead to inflammation and damage to liver cells. This can result in elevated SGPT/ALT levels as liver cells release the enzyme into the bloodstream. While elevated SGPT/ALT levels can be seen in alcohol-related liver damage, it’s important to note that ALT elevation can also occur in other liver diseases, such as viral hepatitis, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), druginduced liver injury, and more. An SGOT/SGPT ratio greater than 2 is highly suggestive of alcoholic hepatitis and cirrhosis. It occurs in 70% of these patients compared with 26% of patients with postnecrotic cirrhosis, 8% with chronic hepatitis, 4% with viral hepatitis and none with obstructive jaundice. Option D. Total billirubin: Elevated Bilirubin Levels: Excessive alcohol consumption can lead to inflammation and damage to liver cells. When the liver is unable to process bilirubin effectively due to this damage, it can lead to an increase in bilirubin levels in the bloodstream. Elevated bilirubin levels may manifest as jaundice, where the skin and whites of the eyes take on a yellowish color However, elevated bilirubin levels can also occur in other liver conditions, such as viral hepatitis, cirrhosis, bile duct obstruction, and other forms of liver disease. Total bilirubin levels may be elevated in infectious hepatitis. Bilirubin levels higher than 30 mg/dL indicate more severe disease.
